questions.question: When carrying a sealed load, the driver:
questions.answerB: Should ensure the weight of the cargo does not violate weight limits.
questions.answerD: Should unseal the load to ensure safety.
questions.explanation: While a driver cannot inspect sealed loads, they can still ensure that the load does not exceed gross weight and axle weight limits.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: What is black ice?
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: A burning tire should be:
questions.explanation: A burning tire should be cooled with water. A driver may need to use large quantities of water to properly cool the tire.

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: When preparing to enter traffic, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Wait for a large gap between vehicles.
questions.answerB: Be prepared for your vehicle to accelerate slowly, especially if it is loaded.
questions.answerC: Make sure you can completely cross traffic, if necessary, without interfering with traffic.
questions.answerD: Assume other drivers will make room for your much larger vehicle.
questions.explanation: When crossing or entering traffic, bear in mind the size of your vehicle and the distance it will need to accelerate. Wait for a gap in traffic that is large enough to accommodate your vehicle before you begin to accelerate. Remember that you will need more room to accelerate if your vehicle is heavily loaded. Before crossing a road, be sure that you can get all the way across without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: To best reduce the distractions of a cell phone, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay on a single call for an entire trip.
questions.answerB: Turn the phone off before driving.
questions.answerC: Only us the phone to accept incoming calls.
questions.answerD: Use the phone to text rather than talk.
questions.explanation: If possible, you should avoid all cell phone distractions by turning it off before starting a trip and leaving it off until you reach your destination.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you can acquire points by:
questions.answerC: Exiting the vehicle one time to check your positioning.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: If coolant has to be added to a system without a recovery tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the vehicle running while adding coolant.
questions.answerC: Not use gloves to touch the radiator cap.
questions.answerD: Wait for the engine to cool before adding coolant.
questions.explanation: Before adding coolant to a system without a recovery or overflow tank, you must turn the engine off and wait until it cools. Use gloves or a thick cloth to protect your hands. To release the pressure seal, turn the radiator cap slowly to the first stop.

questions.question: Extremely hot temperatures can cause:
questions.explanation: Because air expands when hot, tire pressure increases as temperatures increase. This can sometimes result in tire failure. Consistently check your tire pressure when making a trip in hot weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a backing maneuver that you will be asked to perform during the basic control skills test?
questions.explanation: Backing maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right, offset back/left, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW)?
questions.answerA: The total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a vehicle before cargo
questions.answerD: The maximum weight allowed to be transported by a vehicle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle and its load of cargo.

questions.question: What is the penalty for operating a CMV that is placarded for hazardous materials while you are under the influence of alcohol?
questions.answerA: Losing your CDL for three months
questions.answerB: Losing your CDL for six months
questions.answerC: Losing your CDL for one year
questions.answerD: Losing your CDL for three years
questions.explanation: Operating a commercial motor vehicle (CMV) while under the influence of alcohol will normally result in the loss of one's CDL for at least one year. If an operator is under the influence of alcohol while operating a CMV that is placarded for hazardous materials, this increases to at least three years.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: When carrying a wide load, you should:
questions.answerB: Obtain special permits and follow special rules.
questions.answerC: Honk at other drivers to get them to move from the lane closest to you.
questions.explanation: Loads that are over-length, over-width, and/or overweight may require special permits. Drivers of such loads may be subject to special restrictions, such as only being permitted to drive at certain times.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: The vehicle crossing over an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerB: A driver executing a single pull-up.
questions.answerC: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerD: The vehicle stalling while the driver shifts gears.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: Before operating a school bus, ____ should be checked.
questions.explanation: It is essential that school bus drivers check all of the bus's mirrors before operating the vehicle. You should always have a maximum viewing area that is consistent with Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards. If necessary, have the positioning of the mirrors adjusted.

questions.question: While students load and unload a bus, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch the process and keep an eye on the students.
questions.explanation: The driver of a school bus should observe students as they enter or exit the bus to ensure that they are not caught in the door or handrails. It is also important to make sure the students have moved a safe distance away from the unloading area after they have exited the bus.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the necessary traffic checks first.
questions.answerC: Cut off other vehicles if needed to follow the instructions.
questions.answerD: Not make the lane change if you don’t want to.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to make multiple lane changes during the driving skills test. Before changing lanes, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use proper signals. Change lanes smoothly when you can do so safely.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: During the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: A pull-up always counts against the applicant.
questions.answerB: A pull-up should be completed at least once.
questions.answerC: Stopping without changing direction is not considered a pull-up.
questions.answerD: Excessive pull-ups are acceptable in the opinions of some test administrators.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, a pull-up will be scored any time an applicant stops and pulls forward to gain a better position. Stopping without changing direction will not. An excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: Drivers should try to stop ____ away from students at a bus stop.
questions.explanation: A school bus should stop at least 10 feet away from students who are being picked up at a bus stop. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, allowing the driver to observe their movements and better monitor their locations.

questions.question: When should a bus start moving after students have boarded?
questions.answerA: As soon as the students are through the door
questions.answerB: When the students are near their seats but are still standing
questions.answerC: When the students are seated and looking forward
questions.answerD: As soon as the students cross the standee line
questions.explanation: Once students have boarded a school bus, the driver should wait to move the bus until all of the passengers are seated and looking forward.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Stop between 15 and 50 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerB: Stop 100 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerC: Stop 10 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerD: Continue across the tracks without stopping.
questions.explanation: In general, school bus drivers should stop before any railroad crossings to check the tracks for approaching trains. Drivers should stop no closer than 15 feet, and no farther than 50 feet, from the nearest rail in order to have the best view of the tracks. They should look and listen for approaching trains before proceeding through the crossing.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: Where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.
questions.answerB: Where the front of each front tire touches the ground.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus; the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Outside flat mirrors should be adjusted to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the outside right and left side mirrors should be adjusted so the driver can see 200 feet (or four bus lengths) behind the bus.

questions.question: If your bus's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) stops working:
questions.answerA: You will not have any working brakes.
questions.answerB: The brakes will react more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: You will still have normal braking power.
questions.explanation: If its Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, a vehicle will still retain its normal braking power. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: When approaching students at a bus stop, you should stop:
questions.answerA: As close as possible to the students.
questions.answerB: Within an arm’s reach of the students.
questions.answerC: At least 10 feet away from the students.
questions.answerD: About 80 feet away from the students.
questions.explanation: When approaching a bus stop, a school bus driver should come to a full stop at least 10 feet away from the waiting students. By forcing the students to walk to the bus, the driver is better able to keep an eye on their movements and location.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if there is a need.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students.
questions.answerC: May change, depending on weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the proper school district authorities.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not alter the location of a bus stop without written authorization of the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: Outside mirrors on a school bus should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: All mirrors on a school bus should be checked and adjusted before beginning a trip. Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safety of all students and surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: A properly adjusted flat mirror should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: The rear tires touching the ground.
questions.answerB: The front tires touching the ground.
questions.answerC: Only the roadway and no parts of the bus.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see 200 feet behind the bus, the base of each rear wheel, and the sides of the bus.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: The area to the left of a school bus is considered especially dangerous to students because:
questions.answerA: The sun’s reflection obscures the left side of the bus.
questions.answerB: Passing vehicles are located to the left of the bus.
questions.answerC: It is difficult to see the left side of any bus.
questions.answerD: There is no door on the left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: While all sides of a school bus have danger zones, the left side is particularly hazardous to students due to the presence of passing vehicles.

questions.question: If asked to sight-side back your vehicle into an alley, you should first:
questions.answerA: Pull directly into the alley parking space.
questions.answerB: Turn your vehicle to the right to position yourself directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Pull past the alley and stop perpendicular to the outer boundary.
questions.answerD: Pull past the alley and stop parallel to the outer boundary.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the necessary traffic checks first.
questions.answerC: Cut off other vehicles if needed to follow the instructions.
questions.answerD: Not make the lane change if you don’t want to.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to make multiple lane changes during the driving skills test. Before changing lanes, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use proper signals. Change lanes smoothly when you can do so safely.

questions.question: In the event of a bus evacuation, students should be led at least ____ away from the road.
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to evacuate a school bus, students should be led by the driver in the direction of oncoming traffic to a safe location that is at least 100 feet off the road. This will help to ensure that they are not hit by flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus.

questions.question: After students unload at a school, the driver:
questions.answerA: May assume students have taken all of their belongings with them.
questions.answerB: Should assume the students have immediately cleared the doorway.
questions.answerC: Should walk through the bus and check for any sleeping or hiding students.
questions.answerD: May turn off the dispatch radio.
questions.explanation: After students have exited a bus at a school, the driver should walk through the bus to check for any remaining students who are hiding or sleeping. Drivers should also look out for items that students may have left behind.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerA: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: A school bus must be evacuated if:
questions.answerA: The bus has stalled in winter weather conditions.
questions.answerB: The air conditioning system has broken.
questions.answerC: There is any imminent danger of collision.
questions.explanation: During emergency situations, it is usually safest for students to remain on a school bus. Evacuations are mandatory if the bus has stalled on railroad tracks, if the bus is on fire or there is a threat of fire, or if there is a hazardous materials spill. Students should be evacuated any time there is imminent danger of collision.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: Applicants will not have to identify the ABS.
questions.answerB: Windshield wipers are not to be addressed.
questions.answerC: Shock absorbers only need to be checked on one axle.
questions.answerD: The steering box should be checked for leaks.
questions.explanation: During the external inspection portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you must verify that the steering box is securely mounted and not leaking.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume you'll hear an approaching train.
questions.answerB: Rely solely on signals to tell you if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Open the door and listen for a train.
questions.answerD: Immediately proceed after a train has passed.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, do not rely only on signals to tell you if a train is approaching. You should silence all passengers, open the front door, and look and listen for trains. After a train has passed, you should check for another train approaching from either direction before you proceed across the tracks.

questions.question: If your vehicle is equipped with a cargo lift, you should ensure that:
questions.answerD: The lift is the proper color.
questions.explanation: When checking a cargo lift as part of your vehicle inspection test, you should check for leaking, damaged, or missing parts. The lift must be fully retracted and latched securely.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When taking the on-road test, you will be evaluated on regular traffic checks. You should not:
questions.answerC: Avoid checking your mirrors near intersections.
questions.explanation: While taking the on-road driving skills test, check for traffic and use your mirrors regularly, especially when encountering intersections. Scan and check for pedestrians in areas where they may be present.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Generally, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: In general, a shipper is required to list an emergency response telephone number on hazardous materials' shipping papers. There are some exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerA: Does not have to be able to move the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Does not need to know about the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must stay within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading and unloading of a tank must be watched by a qualified person. They must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the materials involved; know the procedures to follow in an emergency; and be authorized and able to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: Shipping papers:
questions.answerA: Are not needed for most shipments.
questions.answerC: Should be stored in a special compartment in the cab.
questions.answerD: Can be kept as a digital file.
questions.explanation: For all shipments of hazardous materials, the shipper must use shipping papers to inform drivers and dockworkers of the risks presented by the cargo.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, what letters will appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.explanation: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: In general, when loading a tank with flammable liquids:
questions.answerB: A ground should be established before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerC: A ground should be broken right before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerD: The filling hole should be locked during loading.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You can proceed without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: You can proceed without stopping if no other vehicles are within sight.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in a certain type of business, such as a fireworks dealer or pest control firm.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The shipper's business is located in a bad part of town.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical supply businesses, or pest control firms.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: After completing hazardous materials transportation training, drivers must have an understanding of:
questions.answerC: How to recognize and respond to possible security threats.
questions.answerD: The effects of relative humidity on hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include an education on how to recognize and respond to possible security threats.

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: What should be done if the third column of the Hazardous Materials Table contains the word “Forbidden?”
questions.answerA: The indicated substance should not be transported.
questions.answerB: The indicated substance should be transported by air.
questions.answerC: The indicated substance should only be transported at night.
questions.answerD: The indicated substance should be accompanied by a security guard.
questions.explanation: The third column of the Hazardous Materials Table lists items' hazard classes and divisions. Drivers should never transport a material that is marked by the word "Forbidden."

questions.question: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes:
questions.answerA: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper if a small piece of paper is being used.
questions.answerB: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper to make them easier to read.
questions.answerC: Should not be abbreviated on a shipping paper.
questions.answerD: Should only be abbreviated on a shipping paper if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes must never be abbreviated when listed on a shipping paper. The only exception to this is if the abbreviation is specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: Can only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Can be driven if it does not contain radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: A vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be appropriately placarded to be driven. An improperly placarded vehicle may only be driven if necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling a distance shorter than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle must be properly placarded before it can be driven. A vehicle that does not display the proper placards may not be moved unless doing so is necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: If cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.answerD: Spray the leaking containers with water.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be placed in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on its side.
questions.answerD: The package should be made of wood.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: Unless it is clearly unsafe, what does a driver need to accept a package?
questions.explanation: When the shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: How is a hazardous materials warning presented?
questions.answerB: By wrapping the package in orange
questions.answerC: By placing the item away from other cargo and covering it with a sign
questions.explanation: Signs are placed on the outside of vehicles and bulk packages to warn drivers and others about hazardous materials. These diamond-shaped signs are known as "placards."

questions.question: Hazardous materials laws are controlled by:
questions.explanation: Because of the risks presented by the nature of the materials, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: The identification number associated with a hazardous material should appear:
questions.answerD: On a bumper sticker on the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It must also appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in the trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to a corrosive material must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: Who is required to provide training for a driver who will transport hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The employer of a driver who will transport hazardous materials, or the employer's designated representative, is required to provide the driver with applicable training and testing.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in a certain type of business, such as a fireworks dealer or pest control firm.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The shipper's business is located in a bad part of town.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical supply businesses, or pest control firms.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package:
questions.answerB: Has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: Was packed at a specific location.
questions.answerD: Will be placed on the trailer first.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they are certifying that the package has been prepared in accordance with its applicable rules.

questions.question: To complete a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest, you must:
questions.answerB: Sign, but only if you cross into another state.
questions.answerC: Sign, but only if the weather was hazardous.
questions.explanation: A Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest must be signed by hand. The name and EPA registration number of the shippers, carriers, and destination must also appear on the manifest.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: Materials that are considered hazardous may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials are products that pose risks to health, safety, and property during transportation. Materials that are considered hazardous include explosives; flammable and poisonous gases; and flammable and other hazardous solids.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: Most drivers are the least alert:
questions.explanation: Fatigue and lack of alertness are major hazards when driving at night. Most people are the least alert at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, be sure to:
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: What can happen if a parking brake is used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.explanation: If you use the parking brakes when the weather is very wet and the temperature is below freezing, the brakes may become frozen, preventing the vehicle from moving.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: If you don't pull the dolly out from beneath the rear trailer before unlocking the pintle hook:
questions.answerA: The tow bar may cause injury.
questions.explanation: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under the rear trailer. This could cause the dolly tow bar to fly up, possibly causing serious injury.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The turn should be made as tightly as possible.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels move in different paths.
questions.answerC: The rear wheels should run over the curb.
questions.answerD: It is acceptable for street signs to be knocked over if they are too close to the road.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: Mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerC: When you are standing next to the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Mirrors should be checked prior to the beginning of a trip. On a vehicle with a trailer, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the connected trailer is straight.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: When preparing to drive in the winter, be sure to check:
questions.explanation: Before driving during the winter, make sure to check your defrosting and heating equipment, coolant and antifreeze levels, wipers and washers, tire tread, tire chains, lights, reflectors, and exhaust system. Clear ice and snow from all windows, mirrors, hand holds, steps, deck plates, and radiator shutters. Make sure the winterfront is not closed too tightly.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerA: Freeze, but only once the temperature drops significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: Freeze after other road surfaces freeze.
questions.answerD: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.explanation: Bridges usually freeze before the rest of the road. You should be especially careful when crossing bridges if the temperature is near the freezing point.

questions.question: When it is difficult for others to see your vehicle, such as at dawn or dusk, you can help other drivers by:
questions.answerD: Waving an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: At times when visibility is low, you should turn your headlights on to the low beam setting. If you are having a difficult time seeing others, they are probably having a difficult time seeing you.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Improper coupling is:
questions.explanation: It is essential that drivers of doubles and triples are able to correctly couple and uncouple their trailers. Improperly coupling and uncoupling trailers is extremely dangerous.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: All air tanks must include:
questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: When inspecting the trailers in double and triple combinations:
questions.answerA: A driver should walk around the trailers.
questions.answerB: A driver should remain in the cab.
questions.answerC: A driver should use their mirrors.
questions.answerD: A driver should board each trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailers in double and triple combinations should be checked in walk-around inspections.

questions.question: If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push the tractor air supply control, you should:
questions.explanation: It is important that all of your vehicle's equipment is in proper working condition before you begin a trip. If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push in the tractor air supply control, you should make sure the air line connections are properly attached and sealed.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely travel under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have space for your vehicle to safely fit underneath an overhead object, slow down and seek an alternate route if possible.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: A sign indicating a maximum safe speed:
questions.answerA: Is suggesting a driving speed, but vehicles may travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.answerB: Is suggesting a speed limit to be followed only by vehicles weighing more than 26,000 pounds.
questions.answerC: Should be followed and no vehicle should travel faster than the posted speed.
questions.explanation: You should never exceed the speed shown on a "Maximum Safe Speed" sign.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: If a traffic light has been green for a long time:
questions.answerA: It will probably stay green as you approach.
questions.answerC: It is likely that the light will soon change to yellow.
questions.answerD: It is likely the light will skip yellow and change from green to red.
questions.explanation: If you are approaching a traffic light that has been green for a long time, there is a good chance that it will turn yellow before you reach it. Start slowing down and be ready to stop.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.answerD: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect:
questions.answerA: Doubles and triples are more likely to turn over than other combination vehicles.
questions.answerB: A combination vehicle will make a loud noise if driven fast enough.
questions.answerC: The tires on a middle trailer will lock up at all stops.
questions.answerD: Vehicles following a truck will be able to travel faster than normal.
questions.explanation: Double and triple trailer combinations are more likely to turn over due to the "crack-the-whip" effect than are other combination vehicles. Drivers should be aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles and steer accordingly.

questions.question: When driving a double, the lightest trailer should be placed:
questions.explanation: For safest handling when driving a double or triple combination vehicle, the most heavily loaded semi-trailer should be placed in the first position behind the tractor. The lightest trailer should be placed in the rear position.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: When driving a double or triple, it is important to remember that:
questions.answerA: The vehicle requires more space than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Other drivers will likely get out of your way when necessary.
questions.answerC: The vehicle likely weighs the same as other vehicles.
questions.answerD: The vehicle can easily fit into small spaces.
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples need more space than other vehicles, both because they are longer than other vehicles and because their size and weight prevent them from turning or stopping suddenly. When driving a double or triple, always make sure you have enough space before entering traffic, crossing traffic, or changing lanes.

questions.question: How are dolly brakes released?
questions.answerA: By opening the air tank petcock
questions.explanation: Release dolly brakes by opening the air tank petcock. If the dolly has spring brakes, use the dolly parking brake control.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Keep your attention focused in front of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look only to the front and sides of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Look to the front, sides, and rear of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle. In addition to watching the road ahead, you should frequently check your mirrors to monitor the road to the sides and to the rear of your vehicle.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to open.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: Drivers are usually the least alert:
questions.explanation: Drivers are usually less alert when driving at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: Due to the risk of liquid surge in tanks, you should:
questions.explanation: Be aware of the risk of liquid surge when driving tanks transporting liquid cargo. To prevent the negative affects of surge on your driving, you should start, slow, and stop very smoothly.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: Driving too fast:
questions.answerA: Is a major cause of fatal crashes.
questions.answerB: Can be a good way to get to your destination quickly.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the roadway is dry.
questions.explanation: Driving at excessive speeds is a major cause of fatal crashes. Never drive above the posted maximum speed limit and adjust your speed to fit conditions.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the vehicle to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble while you are driving, you should stop and inspect the source of the unusual occurrence.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is equipped on a trailer but not on a tractor:
questions.answerA: The truck should not be driven because ABS needs to be on both the tractor and trailer.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: The tractor should not be used and a new tractor with ABS should be located.
questions.answerD: The tractor and trailer can still be used together.
questions.explanation: A vehicle being equipped with anti-lock brakes on only the tractor or only the trailer provides additional control during braking.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of the engine.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.answerD: Should be done on surfaces with poor traction.
questions.explanation: Accelerate smoothly and gradually. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: A combination vehicle has:
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles have two air lines: a service line and an emergency line.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerC: Is usually aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerD: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Driving while distracted may result in slowed perception, delayed decision-making, and improper actions. Watch for distracted drivers and avoid them, when possible.

questions.question: What can change the height of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: Why are roads especially slippery right after it begins to rain?
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerC: Gravel often gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Tires are not usually designed to drive in rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, roads are often at their most slippery when the rain first begins to fall. Fresh rainwater mixes with oil and grease on the road to form a slick film. As the rain continues, this mixture will eventually wash away.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Is not a concern if passengers are not unloading.
questions.answerC: Should not be on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Is a concern, whether passengers are visible or not.
questions.explanation: Always drive cautiously around a stopped bus. Passengers may cross in front of or behind it, and the bus may prevent them from seeing your vehicle.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
