questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling a distance shorter than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle must be properly placarded before it can be driven. A vehicle that does not display the proper placards may not be moved unless doing so is necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When driving through work zones, you should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be placed in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on its side.
questions.answerD: The package should be made of wood.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should never be completed the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be completed in the same order.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely travel under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have space for your vehicle to safely fit underneath an overhead object, slow down and seek an alternate route if possible.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerA: Only occurs at extremely high speeds.
questions.answerB: Can occur at speeds as slow as 30 mph.
questions.answerC: Happens most frequently when tire pressure is too high.
questions.answerD: Happens most frequently when tires have good tread.
questions.explanation: If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph. It is most likely if the tires' air pressure is too low or if tires' tread is worn.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: When making a tight maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your mirrors, as they can be distracting.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors, but not too frequently.
questions.explanation: Make a point of checking your mirrors often when making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you would inspect and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load in a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the CDL vehicle inspection test, you must be able to inspect your vehicle and explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: At railroad crossings, bus drivers:
questions.answerB: Do not need to stop, but must reduce their speed to 25 mph below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Do not need to stop, but must open the door to listen for trains.
questions.answerD: Must stop and check for any approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: In the event of an engine fire, you should not:
questions.answerA: Turn the engine off as soon as possible.
questions.answerD: Spray from the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In the event of an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you can avoid it. Shoot foam through the louvers or from the vehicle’s underside.

questions.question: To make it as safe as possible to leave a stop, you should park:
questions.answerA: So that you must back up to leave your parking space.
questions.answerB: So that you can pull forward to leave your parking space.
questions.answerC: On the side of a roadway, not in a parking lot.
questions.answerD: By backing into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Backing can be dangerous, so avoid doing it whenever you can. If possible, park in such a way that allows you to pull forward to exit your parking space.

questions.question: Once stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the four-way flashers because it is just a test, not an emergency.
questions.answerC: Leave the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Park in front of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: Once you have stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must activate your four-way flashers and shift into neutral or park. You must not block any driveways, intersections, fire hydrants, or signs.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed down gradually.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be pushed down quickly.
questions.answerC: The brake pedal should be pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.answerD: The amount of force required on the brake pedal will be the same each time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Press the brake pedal down smoothly and gradually every time you slow or stop. The amount of brake pressure you need to apply depends on the speed of your vehicle and how quickly you need to stop.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: There may be extra weight in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything behind your vehicle. If you must drive in reverse, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should move your vehicle quickly.
questions.answerB: You should move your vehicle slowly.
questions.answerC: The move should be made with a jerking motion.
questions.answerD: You do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly to maintain control of your vehicle. Doing this will also allow a driver that you did not see time to move out of the way of your vehicle. Use the proper turn signal to communicate with other road users.

questions.question: During the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: A pull-up always counts against the applicant.
questions.answerB: A pull-up should be completed at least once.
questions.answerC: Stopping without changing direction is not considered a pull-up.
questions.answerD: Excessive pull-ups are acceptable in the opinions of some test administrators.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, a pull-up will be scored any time an applicant stops and pulls forward to gain a better position. Stopping without changing direction will not. An excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the vehicle to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble while you are driving, you should stop and inspect the source of the unusual occurrence.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will multiply its braking distance by four.

questions.question: When preparing to drive in the winter, be sure to check:
questions.explanation: Before driving during the winter, make sure to check your defrosting and heating equipment, coolant and antifreeze levels, wipers and washers, tire tread, tire chains, lights, reflectors, and exhaust system. Clear ice and snow from all windows, mirrors, hand holds, steps, deck plates, and radiator shutters. Make sure the winterfront is not closed too tightly.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: Allow the rear wheels to lock up
questions.answerB: Allow all wheels to lock up
questions.answerD: Alert other motorists when you are braking
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: The vehicle crossing over an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerB: A driver executing a single pull-up.
questions.answerC: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerD: The vehicle stalling while the driver shifts gears.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: How many classes of hazardous materials are there?
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: You must put out emergency warning devices within ____ of stopping on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of a road, put out your emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping. When pulling off the road to stop, be sure to turn on your four-way emergency flashers.

questions.question: A bus driver is:
questions.answerA: Exempt from wearing a seat belt.
questions.answerB: Only required to wear a seat belt if the passengers have seat belts.
questions.answerC: Required to wear a seat belt at all times.
questions.answerD: Not required to wear a seat belt, but is encouraged to do so.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus should be equipped with a seat belt. A driver is always required to wear a seat belt while driving a bus.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: The drive shaft should:
questions.answerA: Be bent toward the passenger side.
questions.answerB: Be bent toward the driver’s side.
questions.answerC: Be bent to one side or the other.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you should check that the drive shaft is not bent or cracked.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill:
questions.answerD: You will slow to a stop.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is traveling on a downward slope, the force of gravity will cause its speed to increase.

questions.question: When driving through a curve during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer from your lane if needed to complete the curve.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed after entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Refrain from looking for other vehicles while turning.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving skills test, you must reduce your speed sufficiently before entering the curve so that you do not need to further brake or shift in the curve. Keep the vehicle in its lane and continue to check for traffic in all directions.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerD: Drive faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunctions:
questions.answerB: A yellow lamp will light up on the control panel.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with ABS, a yellow malfunction lamp on the instrument panel will illuminate to alert you if the braking system is not working.

questions.question: A person working on a disabled vehicle on the shoulder of a road:
questions.answerA: Will likely pay attention to traffic on the road.
questions.answerB: May be focused on the repair and not paying attention to roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on disabled vehicles. The task will likely consume their attention, so they may not be aware of traffic or other hazards on the road.

questions.question: If there are no warning gates or lights at a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Not worry because the tracks are likely abandoned.
questions.answerB: Park your vehicle and walk up to the tracks to determine if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Look down the tracks in both directions to ensure that no trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Do whatever surrounding vehicles are doing.
questions.explanation: A passive railroad crossing is a crossing that lacks control devices, like gates or warning lights. Before crossing a passive railroad crossing, you should search the tracks for approaching trains coming from either direction.

questions.question: Which factor does not have an impact on a person’s blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerA: The number of alcoholic drinks consumed
questions.answerB: How quickly the alcoholic drinks were consumed
questions.explanation: The three main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how quickly the alcohol is consumed, and the person's weight.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be helpful to see a wider area.
questions.answerD: Are illegal to be used in most states.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerD: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: A burning tire should be:
questions.explanation: A burning tire should be cooled with water. A driver may need to use large quantities of water to properly cool the tire.

questions.question: When it is difficult for others to see your vehicle, such as at dawn or dusk, you can help other drivers by:
questions.answerD: Waving an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: At times when visibility is low, you should turn your headlights on to the low beam setting. If you are having a difficult time seeing others, they are probably having a difficult time seeing you.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only occur if there is enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can brake 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should continue driving, but turn the emergency flashers on to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning light turns on, you should stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. Controlled braking will be possible only as long as enough air remains in the tanks.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerD: Be especially careful because the brakes may fail.
questions.explanation: You should not apply the brake pedal if the spring brakes are activated. The brakes could be damaged if they are subjected to the force of air pressure and the springs at the same time.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: Which type of brakes do most heavy-duty vehicles have?
questions.explanation: For safety, most heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 55 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 55 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: What happens if the air pressure in a system's air tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light will come on.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will not shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low pressure warning signal should activate if the pressure in the air tanks falls to a level below 60 psi. This signal may be in the form of a warning light or a wig wag.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: Failing to drain the tanks in an air brake system can result in:
questions.answerA: Water freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do this can cause damage. For example, water that has built up in the system could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Maintain full-capacity air pressure in the braking systems even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking systems when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build enough air pressure to brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Do not need time to build air pressure before a trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must allow the air compressor time to build up at least 100 psi of air pressure in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Where is the safety relief valve usually located?
questions.explanation: An air brake system's safety relief valve is located in the tank that is first to receive air from the compressor.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. The belt should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an air brake system with a belt-driven air compressor, it is important to check the condition and tightness of the belt.

questions.question: How is water and compressor oil removed from the bottom of an air storage tank?
questions.answerA: The water and oil are siphoned out of the tank.
questions.answerB: A drain valve is opened to remove the water and oil from the tank.
questions.answerC: The water and oil are removed automatically as the brakes are used.
questions.answerD: A sponge is used to soak up the water and oil.
questions.explanation: Water and compressor oil are removed from air storage tanks through a drain valve. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated tanks must be drained every day to remove this build-up.

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 55 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 55 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: Applying the brake pedal causes air pressure to activate an electric switch and:
questions.answerB: Turn on the low pressure warning light.
questions.answerD: Turn off the low pressure warning light.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by:
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is pushed down, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if it is warm outside.
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand valve while driving:
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: Which type of vehicle is most prone to the “crack-the-whip” effect?
questions.explanation: Triple combination trailers are most vulnerable to the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: A lightly-loaded combination vehicle will stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have high traction.
questions.answerB: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have low traction.
questions.answerC: The brakes only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction on a light trailer than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: One way to prevent a rollover is to:
questions.answerA: Move cargo to the left side of the rig.
questions.answerB: Keep cargo centered on the rig.
questions.answerC: Move cargo to the right side of the rig.
questions.answerD: Keep cargo as far from the ground as possible.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: A shut-off valve:
questions.answerA: Is located on the front of a trailer.
questions.answerB: Is located on the instrument panel.
questions.answerC: Prevents air from escaping an air brake system.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: A trailer will be most likely to swing around when:
questions.explanation: An empty trailer will require a longer stopping distance than a loaded trailer. Additionally, a trailer is most likely to swing out and strike other vehicles when it is lightly loaded or empty.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.

questions.question: To help prevent rollovers, you should:
questions.answerC: Keep the load near the back of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Keep the load on one side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: Before backing your tractor under the trailer, make sure your trailer brakes are:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerA: Does not change braking in any way.
questions.answerC: Will allow the driver additional control over their vehicle when braking.
questions.answerD: Will cause extra strain on the other axles.
questions.explanation: Having an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) on only the trailer, or even on just one axle, will still provide a driver with additional control over the trailer when braking.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, how should you turn the steering wheel?
questions.answerA: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerD: It depends on where the trailer is being backed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once the trailer begins turning, you should then switch the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.answerD: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: One way to prevent a rollover is to:
questions.answerA: Move cargo to the left side of the rig.
questions.answerB: Keep cargo centered on the rig.
questions.answerC: Move cargo to the right side of the rig.
questions.answerD: Keep cargo as far from the ground as possible.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: A trailer will be most likely to swing around when:
questions.explanation: An empty trailer will require a longer stopping distance than a loaded trailer. Additionally, a trailer is most likely to swing out and strike other vehicles when it is lightly loaded or empty.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: When turning right onto a narrow street while operating a long vehicle, you may need to:
questions.explanation: If turning right onto a narrow street while operating a long vehicle, you should approach the corner as you normally would. During the turn, it may be necessary to swing to the left just enough to allow your right rear wheels to have curb clearance. You should not swing so far left that another driver could attempt to pass you on the right.

questions.question: The load limit for a vehicle may depend on:
questions.answerA: The speed limits on the planned route.
questions.answerC: The weather conditions on the route.
questions.answerD: The number of axles on the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Load limits vary from vehicle to vehicle. Each vehicle's limit depends on its size, the number of axles on the vehicle, the distance between the axles, and the size of the tires on the vehicle.

questions.question: Mud flaps should be equipped within ____ of the surface of the road.
questions.explanation: When required on a vehicle, mud flaps or safety guards should be equipped within eight inches of the surface of the road. Safety guards or mud flaps are required behind the rear wheels of a vehicle with four or more tires on its rear axle.

questions.question: If a chain, rope, or cable is being used to tow a vehicle, a ____ flag should also be attached.
questions.explanation: If a chain, rope, or cable is being used to tow a vehicle, a white flag that is at least 12 square inches should be attached to the connector. The connecting chain, rope, or cable should not be longer than 15 feet.

questions.question: When turning right in a long vehicle, you should approach the corner at a distance of about ____ from the curb.
questions.explanation: When turning right in a long vehicle, such as a tractor-trailer or bus, you should make sure the rear wheels have curb clearance. To help ensure this clearance, you can approach the curb at a distance of about four feet, then turn wide to the right as soon as the front wheels pass the corner.

questions.question: If you must make an emergency stop on the side of a roadway and your vision is obscured, you should place a warning signal between ____ behind your vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important that all commercial motor vehicle drivers carry the proper emergency equipment in their vehicles at all times. If you must make an emergency stop on the side of a roadway where your vision is obscured, you should place a warning signal between 100 and 500 feet behind your vehicle.

questions.question: A combination used exclusively to transport pipes or poles:
questions.answerA: May never exceed the legal limit for a load extending over the front or rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is required to exceed the legal limit for a load extending over the front or rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: May exceed the legal limit for a load extending over the front or rear of a vehicle, if necessary.
questions.answerD: Should always be shorter than the maximum legal length limit for a vehicle.
questions.explanation: A vehicle or combination that is used exclusively to transport pipes or poles may exceed the legal limit for a load extending over the front or rear of a vehicle, if necessary. A load extending past the rear of a vehicle should always be properly marked with a red flag.

questions.question: If you must make an emergency stop on the side of a roadway and your vision is obscured, you should place the first warning signal ____ behind your vehicle.
questions.explanation: When making an emergency stop on the side of any road, a warning signal should be placed 10 feet behind the vehicle. Depending on what the situation requires when your view is obstructed, you should also place a warning signal 100 feet in front of your vehicle and between 100 and 500 feet behind your vehicle.

questions.question: Farm tractors and other vehicles using wheels with cleats, lugs, flanges, studs, or spikes are not permitted to operate:
questions.explanation: Farm tractors and other vehicles may not operate on highways if equipped with wheels using cleats, lugs, flanges, studs, or spikes. Wheels with extensions on the rims that could damage a road are also not permitted to be used on highways.

questions.question: In Texas, a combination may be made up of no more than:
questions.explanation: In Texas, combinations may be made up of three or fewer vehicles. If traveling on the interstate, you should be aware of combination regulations for each state in which you will be driving.

questions.question: Drive below the posted speed limit when:
questions.answerB: Driving on a highway where there are other cars.
questions.answerC: Anything makes conditions less than perfect.
questions.answerD: You are on a four-lane road.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to drive at a speed too fast for conditions, regardless of the posted speed limit. Any time conditions are less than perfect, you should adjust your speed and following distance.

questions.question: When passing, you should:
questions.answerD: Keep as much space as possible between your vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When passing, you should keep as much space as possible between your vehicle and other vehicles. Be aware that your vehicle produces a buffer of wind that can be dangerous to smaller vehicles nearby.

questions.question: Generally, the total width of a vehicle hauling a load may be no more than:
questions.explanation: Generally, the total width of a vehicle hauling a load may be no more than 102 inches. There are some exceptions to this regulation.

questions.question: In general, when approaching a railroad grade crossing, a school bus driver should:
questions.explanation: Generally, school buses carrying passengers should stop before passing over railroad grade crossings. The driver should ensure there are no trains coming from either direction before continuing. However, if an officer directs the driver to continue over the tracks without stopping, the driver should follow the officer's direction.

questions.question: If a semitrailer must be parked on the shoulder of a roadway where the view is obstructed, and flags are being used in the place of lighted lamps, the flags should be placed:
questions.answerA: In front of and behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only in front of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: On the front and rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a commercial motor vehicle must be parked on the shoulder of a roadway where the view is obstructed, and flags are being used in the place of lighted lamps, the flags should be placed both in front of and behind the vehicle. The flag in the front should be 100 feet away from the vehicle, and the flag to the rear should be between 100 and 500 feet away from the vehicle.

questions.question: You may tailgate:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle in front of you is traveling under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: When traveling under speeds of 35 mph.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle in front of you has a slow-moving emblem.
questions.explanation: Tailgating is dangerous and can cause frustration in other drivers on the roadway. A good professional driver maintains a safe following distance of at least four seconds under ideal driving conditions, or six to eight seconds under poor conditions.

questions.question: If you are driving at night and are hauling a load that extends more than four feet past the rear of your vehicle, you should attach ____ to the rearmost point of the load.
questions.explanation: At night, if you are hauling a load that extends more than four feet beyond the rear of the vehicle, you are required to attach a burning red light to the rearmost point of the load. The light must be visible for at least 500 feet.

questions.question: During the day, if your vehicle is carrying a load that extends more than four feet beyond the rear of your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Attach two white reflectors to the sides of the load.
questions.answerB: Attach a red flag to the rearmost point of the load.
questions.answerC: Attach a red lamp to the side of the load.
questions.answerD: Attach a yellow flag to the rearmost point of the load.
questions.explanation: If you are driving during the day while carrying a load that extends more than four feet beyond the rear of your vehicle, you are required to attach a red flag to the rearmost point of the load. The red flag should be at least 12 square inches.

questions.question: A motor vehicle used to transport cotton seeds may not exceed ____ in length.
questions.explanation: A motor vehicle used to transport cotton seeds, cotton, or equipment used to process cotton may not exceed 48 feet in length.

questions.question: Two ____ clearance lamps are required on the top rear corners of any bus more than 80 inches in width.
questions.explanation: Two red clearance lamps are required on the top rear corners of any bus more than 80 inches in width. The top front corners must be equipped with two amber clearance lamps.

questions.question: In general, when approaching a railroad grade crossing, a school bus driver should:
questions.explanation: Generally, school buses carrying passengers should stop before passing over railroad grade crossings. The driver should ensure there are no trains coming from either direction before continuing. However, if an officer directs the driver to continue over the tracks without stopping, the driver should follow the officer's direction.

questions.question: Passing a motorcycle while driving a semitrailer:
questions.answerA: Is the same as passing any other vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should be done with extra caution.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a large vehicle, be especially cautious when passing a motorcycle or bicycle. Since they are much lighter than other vehicles, they're more prone to be negatively affected by the wind created by large vehicles.

questions.question: If you need to enter a driveway to park, it is a good idea to:
questions.answerD: Refuse the help of another individual.
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to park in a driveway, you should enter the driveway by backing into the space. This way, when leaving the driveway, you can pull forward and clearly see where you are going.

questions.question: If a semitrailer must be parked on the shoulder of a two-way roadway and flags are being used in the place of lighted lamps, the flags should be placed:
questions.answerA: 100 feet in front of and behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: 100 and 200 feet in front of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: 300 feet in front of and behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If lighted lamps are not required to be used during an emergency stop, they should be replaced by two red flags. If a semitrailer must be parked on the shoulder of a two-way roadway and flags are being used in the place of lighted lamps, the flags should be placed 100 feet in front of and behind the vehicle.

questions.question: If traveling down a hill, a commercial motor vehicle:
questions.answerA: Should be shifted into a high gear.
questions.answerB: May not coast down the grade.
questions.answerD: Should be close to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: When driving a commercial motor vehicle down a hill, you should control the speed by switching into a low gear and supplementing with engine braking. It would be unlawful to coast the vehicle down the grade.

questions.question: On trucks, truck tractors, semitrailers, pole trailers, and buses that are at least 80 inches in width, reflectors should be placed between ____ from the ground.
questions.explanation: On trucks, truck tractors, semitrailers, pole trailers, and buses that are at least 80 inches in width, reflectors should be placed between 24 and 60 inches from the ground. Be sure to know the reflector requirements for your specific vehicle.

questions.question: A special permit will be required if you wish to drive a vehicle:
questions.answerA: More slowly than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: That is hauling an empty trailer.
questions.answerD: That is hauling a load larger than the legal limits.
questions.explanation: If a driver needs to haul a load that is heavier, longer, wider, or higher than is legally permitted, the driver must first obtain a special permit. If the load is seen as being easy to dismantle, the permit will not be granted.

questions.question: Two ____ clearance lamps are required on the top front corners of any trailer more than 80 inches in width.
questions.explanation: Two amber clearance lamps are required on the top front corners of any trailer more than 80 inches in width. The top rear corners must be equipped with two red clearance lamps.

questions.question: Flashing lights are permitted on emergency vehicles, snow plows, tow trucks, and:
questions.explanation: Flashing lights are permitted on emergency vehicles, snow plows, and school buses. Flashing lights are permitted on tow trucks when directed by law enforcement on the scene of an accident.

questions.question: A farm tractor operated on a highway at night should be equipped with ____ on the rear.
questions.explanation: If operated at night on a highway, a farm tractor must be equipped with a white light on the front of the vehicle that is visible for 1,000 feet. The rear of the tractor must have two red lights visible for 1,000 feet, or one red light visible for 1,000 feet and two red reflectors visible for 600 feet.

questions.question: Between the half hour after sunset and the half hour before sunrise, a driver should make sure their vehicle is carrying:
questions.answerB: Three flares, three electric lanterns, or three portable red emergency reflectors.
questions.answerD: One flare, one electric lantern, and one portable red emergency reflector.
questions.explanation: It is important for drivers of commercial motor vehicles to keep emergency equipment in their vehicles. A bus, truck tractor, or truck should carry at least three flares, three red electric lanterns, or three portable red emergency reflectors when being driven at a time between a half hour after sunset and a half hour before sunrise.

questions.question: When passing a two-wheeled vehicle on your right, be sure to leave at least ____ to the left of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Use extra caution when passing a two-wheeled vehicle. Be sure to leave at least six feet of space between the two vehicles to ensure everyone's safety.

questions.question: Except for a truck tractor-trailer combination, no combination of vehicles may be more than ____ in total length.
questions.explanation: You must make sure that your vehicle's measurements do not exceed legal limits. Except for a truck tractor-trailer combination, no combination of vehicles may be more than 65 feet in total length.

questions.question: If you must make an emergency stop on the side of a roadway and your vision is obscured, you should place the first warning signal ____ behind your vehicle.
questions.explanation: When making an emergency stop on the side of any road, a warning signal should be placed 10 feet behind the vehicle. Depending on what the situation requires when your view is obstructed, you should also place a warning signal 100 feet in front of your vehicle and between 100 and 500 feet behind your vehicle.

questions.question: If their vehicle becomes disabled, a truck driver should ____ before doing anything else.
questions.answerA: Put out the proper warning signals
questions.answerB: Wave to other drivers for help
questions.answerD: Walk to the nearest exit and find help
questions.explanation: It is important for CMV drivers to ensure they are carrying proper emergency equipment at all times. If a truck becomes disabled while being driven on a highway, the first thing the driver should do is communicate with other drivers on the road by using the proper flares, flags, or reflectors.

questions.question: The rear of every truck, semitrailer, pole trailer, and bus is required to display:
questions.explanation: Two red reflectors should be attached to the rear of any truck, truck tractor, semitrailer, pole trailer, or bus at a height of 24 to 60 inches. These reflectors may be combined with the taillights.

questions.question: If you are driving at night and are hauling a load that extends more than four feet past the rear of your vehicle, you should attach ____ to the rearmost point of the load.
questions.explanation: At night, if you are hauling a load that extends more than four feet beyond the rear of the vehicle, you are required to attach a burning red light to the rearmost point of the load. The light must be visible for at least 500 feet.

questions.question: When transporting loose materials on a flatbed trailer, a driver should make sure the load is:
questions.answerA: Covered entirely by a canvas or tarp.
questions.answerB: Strapped to the bed of the trailer by rope or cable.
questions.answerC: Chained securely to the bed of the truck.
questions.answerD: Adhered to the bed of the truck.
questions.explanation: When operating a flatbed trailer to transport a load of loose materials, such as gravel or sand, the driver must make sure that the materials will not spill or blow onto the roadway. To do this, the driver should securely cover the load entirely with a tarp, canvas, or other covering.

questions.question: Drive below the posted speed limit when:
questions.answerB: Driving on a highway where there are other cars.
questions.answerC: Anything makes conditions less than perfect.
questions.answerD: You are on a four-lane road.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to drive at a speed too fast for conditions, regardless of the posted speed limit. Any time conditions are less than perfect, you should adjust your speed and following distance.

questions.question: The connection between two vehicles when one is being towed should be no longer than:
questions.explanation: Generally, when one vehicle is being towed by another, the cable, chain, rope, drawbar, or other connection should not be any longer than 15 feet. This limit does not apply to pole trailers.
